raw_text:
IMF 'cuts' German growth estimate
 
 The International Monetary Fund is to cut its 2005 growth forecast for the German economy from 1.8% to 0.8%, the Financial Times Deutschland reported.
 
 The IMF will also reduce its growth estimate for the 12-member eurozone economy from 2.2% to 1.6%, the newspaper reported. The German economy has been faltering, with unemployment levels rising to a seventy-year high of 5.2 million. Its sluggish performance continues to hamper the entire eurozone.
 
 The IMF's draft World Economic Outlook - due to be published in April - would point to a marked deterioration in Germany's economy, the FT report said.
 
 In September, the IMF had said that German growth for the current year would be 1.8%. The IMF has also revised eurozone forecasts, the paper said, taking into account high oil prices, the strength of the euro and weak demand in many of the world's leading economies. Europe's economic difficulties have been highlighted by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which argued in a report published on Tuesday that the continent could only achieve US living standards by freeing up its labour markets. "The eurozone does not look like it has a self-sustaining recovery," James Carrick, an economist with ABN Amro, told the newspaper. "It is too dependant on the rest of the world."
llama3.2:1b: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) will cut its German growth forecast to 0.8% from 1.8%, while also reducing eurozone forecasts by 0.2% to 1.6%.
The IMF had previously estimated Germany's growth at 1.8% for the current year, but now expects it to decline further due to high oil prices and weak demand in other major economies.
llama3.2:3b: IMF cuts German growth forecast from 1.8% to 0.8%, eurozone from 2.2% to 1.6%.
Germany's economy falters with high unemployment.
IMF draft World Economic Outlook highlights marked deterioration.
Europe's labor markets must be freed up for self-sustaining recovery, according to OECD report.
gemma2:2b: The IMF is reducing its 2005 growth forecasts for Germany and the Eurozone from 1.8% to 0.8% and 2.2% to 1.6%, respectively.
This follows a rise in unemployment in Germany to 7-year high levels, impacting the entire Eurozone economy.
The IMF will release its World Economic Outlook report in April with further analysis of these revisions.
qwen2.5:0.5b: IMF cuts German growth forecast from 1.8% to 0.8%, eurozone growth estimate reduced from 2.2% to 1.6%.
Europe's economic difficulties highlighted by Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) lowers its 2005 growth estimate for Germany from 1.8% to 0.8%, and also adjusts eurozone forecasts from 2.2% to 1.6%.
This follows high oil prices, a strong euro, and weak global demand.
The IMF's World Economic Outlook is expected in April.
qwen2.5:3b: IMF cuts German growth estimate from 1.8% to 0.8% for 2005, reducing eurozone forecast from 2.2% to 1.6%.
This reflects Germany's faltering economy with rising unemployment (to 5.2 million), affecting the entire eurozone.
IMF’s draft World Economic Outlook will highlight marked deterioration in Germany’s performance.
Previous IMF forecast for German growth was 1.8%, adjusted due to high oil prices, strong euro and weak global demand.
The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development highlights Europe's economic difficulties, suggesting labor market reforms are needed for self-sustaining recovery.
Economist James Carrick from ABN Amro notes the eurozone depends on other world economies for its recovery.
opencoder:1.5b: "IMF 'cuts' German growth estimate The International Monetary Fund is to cut its 2005 growth forecast for the German economy from 1.8% to 0.8%.

The IMF will also reduce its growth estimate for the 12-member eurozone economy from 2.2% to 1.6% The German economy has been faltering, with unemployment levels rising to a seventy-year high of 5.2 million.
Its sluggish performance continues to hamper the entire eurozone."
The IMF's draft World Economic Outlook - due to be published in April - would point to a marked deterioration in Germany's economy.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its 2005 growth forecast for Germany from 1.8% to 0.8%.
It also revised its 12-member eurozone growth estimate, accounting for high oil prices, the strength of the euro, and weak demand in other leading economies.
Germany's economy is underperforming with high unemployment at around 5.2 million jobs, hindering recovery efforts even if labor markets were free.
The IMF's World Economic Outlook for April will reflect this decline.
In September, the forecast was revised downward from 1.8% to 1.6%.
tinyllama:1.1b: The International Monetary Fund cut its forecast for German growth from 2005 to 1.8% in its World Economic Outlook report due to a decline in consumer spending and increased business uncertainty.
The IMF also reduced its forecast for the eurozone, which includes Germany, from 3.4% to 1.6%.

The German economy has been struggling with high unemployment and weak demand, while the eurozone's poor economic performance is attributed to a combination of high oil prices, weaker demand in Europe's leading economies, and low investor confidence.
The IMF's updated forecasts suggest that Germany will perform even worse than previously estimated, with a projected growth rate of 1.8%.
The report also cautioned that Europe may only achieve living standards by freeing up its labour market.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has reportedly cut its forecast for Germany's growth in 2005 to 0.8%, from a previous estimate of 1.8%.

This revision follows a Financial Times report suggesting that the eurozone's economic difficulties have been highlighted by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), which argued in a report that Europe could only achieve US living standards by freeing up its labor markets.

The change reflects growing concern about the sustainability of Eurozone growth, with the OECD suggesting that Germany's GDP growth may be revised downward in coming months as a result of these concerns.
The IMF's draft World Economic Outlook is set to be published later this month, which will provide further insights into the state of the global economy.
phi:2.7b: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded its growth estimates for both Germany and the eurozone, citing rising unemployment levels in Germany and sluggish performance that is affecting the whole eurozone.
In September, the IMF had predicted a growth rate of 1.8% for Germany, but this has now been revised to 0.8%.
The eurozone growth forecast has also been reduced from 2.2% to 1.6%, with weak demand in many leading economies being cited as a contributing factor.

Europe's economic difficulties have been highlighted by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) who argue that the continent needs to free up its labour markets in order to achieve US living standards.
orca-mini:3b: The IMF is expected to reduce its growth forecast for Germany's economy from 1.8% to 0.8%.
Unemployment levels in Germany have reached a seventy-year high of 5.2 million, hampering the entire eurozone.

The eurozone's economic difficulties have been highlighted by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which argued in a report published on Tuesday that the continent could only achieve US living standards by freeing up its labor markets.
hermes3:3b: IMF lowers German growth forecast to 0.8% (from 1.8%) and eurozone forecast to 1.6% (from 2.2%).
stablelm-zephyr:3b: IMF reduces Germany's growth forecast to 0.8% in 2005 and the eurozone's to 1.6%.

High unemployment levels (5.2 million) and weak demand contribute to poor economic performance across Europe, with the OECD suggesting labor market freedoms are necessary for achieving US living standards.

Germany's struggling economy, marked by record-high unemployment of 5.2 million, is dragging down the eurozone.
The IMF's upcoming World Economic Outlook will highlight Germany's economic deterioration, influenced by high oil prices, a strong euro, and weak global demand.
The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has suggested that Europe can only reach US living standards by liberalizing its labor markets.
Economist James Carrick noted that the eurozone lacks a self-sustaining recovery and remains too dependent on global economic conditions.
stablelm2:1.6b: The IMF has lowered German and eurozone growth estimates from 1.8% to 0.8% and 2.2% to 1.6%, respectively.
Germany's unemployment levels are high at 5.2 million, contributing to its sluggish performance.
The IMF's draft World Economic Outlook in April will show a significant deterioration in Germany's economy.
The organization took into account factors like high oil prices, the strength of the euro, and weak demand in major economies when revising the forecasts.

Europe's economic issues have been highlighted by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which argues that the continent can only achieve US living standards by opening its labor markets.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) plans to lower its 2005 growth forecast for Germany from 1.8% to 0.8%, and for the eurozone as a whole from 2.2% to 1.6%.
This downward revision reflects Germany's worsening economic performance, with unemployment reaching 5.2 million, its highest level in seventy years.
The IMF attributes this decline to factors like high oil prices, the euro's strength, and weak global demand.
Economists, including James Carrick of ABN Amro, warn that Europe's economic recovery is unlikely to achieve US living standards due to the continent's over-reliance on world markets.
